title: Workshop on semantic search - Microsearch: An Interface for Semantic Search
segmentation: OK so welcome everyone.
I hope you're still awake after some coffee.
So this presentation was originally only about Mike Research, which is a research prototype that I developed.

But I'm going to tell you a little bit about search monkey, which is a product from from Yahoo itself, and it features some of the ideas behind Mike Research, so you might be interested in seeing how an idea from research have been implanted in in a product, but in a slightly different way.
Then, of course it was imagined by the researcher.
Who would be me?

So just to give you a very brief overview what's what's going on here first I would like to say that this stock is a bit different from the previous talk and that it's not going to be about changing the core search algorithms that we're using, but I'm going to talk about how to change the interface that is being used by the search engine.
So what we've seen before is two kinds of trends in search.
If you will.

One is horizontal search, where you find the big search engine providers like Yahoo, Google, Microsoft, where basically large scale crawling and indexing is performed and matching is almost always keyword based.
So very simple, but very fast techniques.
And in this domain that have been limited experiments with ontologies mostly using ontologies for for query expansion with some success.
On the other hand, what you find is.

Is the domain of vertical search, which is to say search focus on on particular domains such as shopping where you have basically a richer representation of the objects that the user is looking for and also richer richer query query interfaces and result displays but limited to a particular domain.
And there are some combinations which try to do vertical search on a web scale.
So in this category you find something like Google Base or Google Cop.
Which is web scale but again fixed to particular domains.

So there are certain kind of items you can you can upload to Google Base for example, and there are certain kinds of properties you can use to describe those objects, but it's still limited to those objects and those properties.
So the question is then, can we do better with semantic web technologies?
It is particular addressing the long tail of queries I can actually quote a number from a paper by by Riccardo and so my colleagues in Barcelona.
Who have done some query log analysis and actually found that 88% of the unique queries are basically asked once in a year.
So very few people realize you know how long this long tail is.
It's very long actually.
The queries that I asked only once in a year are the majority of the queries.
So this is what we're going to look at.
This is just a slide to again help you Orient yourself.
There are basically two kinds of visions of the semantic web that people talk about these days, and it's important to clarify which one are we targeting.
Because sometimes discussions arise between people who talk about one part of the vision versus people talk about the other part of the vision.
One part is concerned with bringing databases to the semantic web and and linking that data using using web technology.
Another part is concerned with with annotating webpages themselves.
So the first part I would call the data web.
The second part I would call the annotated web.
And slightly different techniques apply to this to these two cases, so that's why it's important to distinguish them, and this presentation is going to be about the annotated web.
So how to how to bring semantics to web pages?
I'll give you a.
Very, very brief history because I don't want to spend a lot of time on this.
Basically the story started somewhere around 1995 or the first versions of HTML.
You could put some simple metadata into the page.

Is these are called meta tags, but this is a technique that still exists, but since this was pre ontology there was basically none of the techniques that we know today as the semantic web have been used in this area.
There have been some early ontology based example.
So this is a nod to our forefathers.
So for example the work by half linen handler on shoe which was about putting RDF.
Well this is actually pre RDF.
Let's say putting ontologies putting ontologies into.
Into HTML.
And ever you know, very in.
Our faces and systems build around it, so basically a lot of this.
Things that we can do today were already there, but simply the technology.
He's under standards were not mature enough to gain mass usage.
And then you had methods like.
What Creative Commons use at the beginning?
Simply a blob of a blob of RDF in HTML is again not very appealing.
And then things have evolved so.
We started to come to the area of or the age of microformats around 2003.
There you have basically HTML attributes such as class being used to mark part of the page.
S value of some property.
So microformats.
Have gained some some traction because they are actually very very easy to alter.
There's some problems if you look at it from from a semantic web perspective, in that microformats have no shared syntax.
So basically each microformat is a syntax on its own.
Describes not only vocabulary, but also how to encode that into into HTML.
They're also not ontologies, so there are no formal descriptions of the schema.
There's very limited reuse that they offer because of that.
So there's basically no extensibility, no data types, no namespaces, so very, very simple, almost tagging like.
Representation.
But yet since it's it's simple, it has gained that user.
On the web.
Another kind of of annotation that we've seen, which is which is, again, was.
Is proprietary to particular systems on how to access this information is tagging and the idea of.
Or farm machine tags as you see it in Flickr.
Again, I'm not going to go into details.
So and then we come to the first solutions to.
To actually use.
RDF, in a microformat style, and that is that is basically using RDF to annotate the content of web pages using HTML attributes.
And the first solution that we've seen was was the RDF.
Beach is a very straightforward mapping, actually of RDF.
Triples 2 onto HTML.
It's a bit more complex than microformats to alter.
Simply because you can use any RDF vocabulary to create the RDF annotations.
So while with microformats you're basically picking a microformat with the RDF, you need to find an ontology right that you can use to mark up your page.
It is more limited in RDF, so there is.
You cannot express any kind of any kind of RDF graph in any RDF, for example, there are no blank nodes and no data types.
You cannot make statements about subjects other than the current document or or resources inside defined inside the namespace of the current document.
And Leslie.
And very Fortunately, the WCC has picked up on this trend and put forward a proposal called our DFA which is currently less called document.
It is similar in intent to the RDF, but provides full RDF support.

Of course there is still the question of user complexity to be seen, but up to now we see this as the ideal solution to the problem and that there is a very straightforward mapping to RDF triples, and also you can encode basically any kind of RDF information that you want.
And it is a standard or soon to become a standard.
Or recommendation as it's called.
OK, so so we.
We observe this trend.
So the question is basically when I started to work at Yahoo Research, you know people came to me and said OK, but so how much of this metadata is out there?
So is this something that you know we should be interested in?
And if there's some some of this metadata out there then then really, what is the quality of it?

So the most terrible idea that I could come up with and anyone could come up with is just try to show how much of this data there is by bringing it to the surface of search onto this search interface.
So this is the very simple idea of the Microsoft prototype.
How it works is that the user comes to this page.
It looks very much like the regular Yahoo search engine.
The user enters a query and then the system fetches the search results as it will do in the regular search engine.
And then each page is also inspected if it contains some kind of metadata.
There is some entity reconciliation, that is that is carried out but very simple.
And mostly what happens is that the metadata is used to enrich the display.
So there are some rich abstracts that are generated.
I'm going to show you in a second.
The metadata is used to reorganize pages and also to show information on on the map and on the timeline.
So here's an example so.
This is a query that asks for Ivan Herman, who is obviously a valuable member of our community, so he's very diligent in annotating his pages so you find lots of metadata.
What you see is, I generate this kind of reach abstract, which replaces well.
It actually does not replace, but appears above the textual summary of the page, and it shows the photo of IBM and some other metadata.
Also you can reorganize pages based on metadata, so you can.
You can put Ivan's blog next to his, his other personal page because simply in the metadata you find a link between the two.
You can also put locations that you find on the map and you can also visualize events on the timeline.
And these events actually come can come from multiple sources, right?
So from any of the result pages.
In this case, there are some events that come from his personal page and some from LinkedIn, which is a profile site.
Here's another example where you can see how how the map works in aggregate are across the result pages.
So here we are asking for all users named Peter on the side Flickr and basically what you see on the map is are the locations of the users.
Another example in this case.
Yes, it's the timeline that serves as an aggregate.
Are you asking for summer school conferences and what you see is basically metadata related to conferences shown on the timeline?
An idea that I already had at the time is that you can go a bit further and actually allow the user to take some actions on the search interface.
So for example, if you find a phone number in the metadata you can put in a direct link so that the user can call that phone number, for example via Skype.
So this is great right?
Because the user saves time.
And it's also good for us.
Fortunately, because the user spends more time on the search result page.
There are some case.
Is where this failed.
So in this case the user search for his name, which is actually the most common query that people tried and then the user gets to see his expected date of death.
Which is kind of shocking.
What happens here is that there is a page where where his name does not appear, but both his first name and his last name appears an.
It also contains metadata about the expected date of death of that particular user, who is not him.
So it's kind of a disambiguation failure.
I do find it funny that some bloggers put their expected date of death on their blocks.
So some of the lessons other than this.

There has been more methods than we expected, although this is hardly scientific in the sense that people who have come to this site and entered queries mostly entered their own names, which is actually turns out to be a very rich source of metadata.
S already most of or some of the large profile sites expose some metadata.
It was very clear that performance is poor in this scenario.
Obviously you cannot do this this online extraction, so metadata has to come from the index.
We've also seen that there's some metal crap out there, so it does happen.
That there is some error, for example.
And this just reinforced us in in the idea that.
That metadata has to come to the surface because otherwise users will not be able to spot these mistakes in their notations and either corrected themselves or warn, warn others to correct it.
A more technical point, this system has used in RDF templating mechanism called fennel, which added some extra complexity so it was it was cut in search monkey, which does not do RDF templating.
And scalability was a was a problem.
So what is search monkey and now?
You're shifting here too, to an actual product that exists today and you can go and play with it.
Search monkeys taking some of these ideas, in particular the idea of generating rich abstracts for the search interface.
What you can do is search monkeys.
Basically, write plugins or extensions to the search interface.
And these plugins are extensions.
At this moment the only thing they do is to modify the abstract part of the page.
But obviously there are going to be further applications coming along.
Why do we think this is good or interesting?

Well, first of all, it's a motivation for for content publishers to implement semantic annotations, because if you're putting out some content on the semantic web so far it didn't make much sense right there.
There were a lack of applications, so we got this chicken and egg problem of not enough applications, not enough data and backwards.
Publishers will be interested in creating these abstracts because they obviously want kind of presentation on the search result page that attracts users.
Why is this interesting for developers?
Well, it's a pretty cool application because I think most of developers are actually itching to do something with the search interface.
If you looked at what happened in terms of the evolution of the search, interface is basically what you see.
Is that all the big search engine providers the agreed on on the search interface, right?
That works that we know today.
And that's probably because that's the search interface that works for every query in general, right?
It works for for the average query.
The problem is that it's not a particularly good interface for any particular query, right?
So I will be very hard pressed to find a single query to which the answer is is an ordered list of 10 pages, right?
So maybe if someone asked for the first 10 pages, the Bible and you have to return it in order and exactly those 10.
Maybe that's an example.

But otherwise, if you think about, for example, the experience that you get when you type in Pablo Picasso in a search engine and experience, you get in Wikipedia for Pablo Picasso, there is a world of difference in terms of presentation in how the content is put together, how multimedia items are placed, how information is presented according to the type of of information.
So there is a long way to go in in customizing the search interface.
That is to say that.
So also search Maggie relies on semantic web technology and that's that.
Brings us back to the original motivation of addressing the long tail of variant content production.
So to basically to be able to do this not only for certain types of objects, not only for persons and calendars but also for Japanese manga movies.
If someone is interested in that.
75 technology is actually used in a number of ways.
We have a for medical data RSS which is a way for people to submit metadata which is actually using our DFA itself.
We are supporting microformats, RDF, A&E, RDF's input format and also be recommending the users to use industry standard vocabularies such as Dublin Core Info.
So this is what these rich abstracts look like.
Here is a more detailed view of what you can do.
We did so at the moment.
You can.
You can fill this template so you're not completely free in this kind of presentation, which is called an enhanced result.
But you can choose what image, what links, and what metadata to show.
You have a second kind of application which is called an infobar.
There very much more free on providing HTML markup.
The difference between the info bar and the enhance result is that this one is not open, it just opens when the user clicks the down arrow, so the user roles it down basically.
So here's a.
Overview of how it works.
So think of your typical website that is generated from some some database.
Which is by the way, we know roughly 7080% of the web that is generated from a database.
If there is some RDF or microformat markup, then we collect that, so that's the Yahoo crawlers part and it's it's been doing that for awhile, for microformats.
It's already doing it for the RDF, Ann will start soon with our DFA.
People can feed in information, so that's this.
Data RSS format.
People can write page extraction applications.
This is a separate kind of application and the only thing these applications do is to extract some structured information from a web page.
So you can write a page extraction module for for Amazon, for example.
And even if Amazon doesn't have a feed or it doesn't have microformat information, you can still extract the structured data and it will as well go into the search index.

Lastly, you have the possibility to wrap APIs, so if there is a website that is a database which it exposes through an API, you can wrap that and the beauty of all of that is that all this data at the end of the day is converted into triples, and it's basically stored in a triple based format in the search index.
And then basically either the person who provided their information or anyone else can come by and write an application that generates.
This rich result.
And very important.
So how does the user get to see this?
So the user basically has the possibility to choose which kind of applications he wants to run.
So there is a Gallery where you can choose that.
I want.
I want the LinkedIn application and I want the Amazon application and so on and so forth.
And that's very important, because obviously we're not all the same, so some users like more.
These kind of rich results.
Some users prefer the traditional results.
Just to give.
Yeah, flavor of how it works so.
So basically this is the interface that you see when you go to search monkey.
There actually three parts.
One is where you can create and manage your representation applications.
One is where you can create and manage your custom data services, and there's a third part where you can upload feeds, so this kind of data feeds.
The way you develop an application.
And as you give the name, you say which kind of application you're developing.
And then you're basically selecting the source data that you want to use.
There's a step that I skipped here.
There's actually a Step 2 very.
Also choose the URLs on which your application is going to be working.
So currently you write an application against a pattern of URLs, and that's going to change.

I assume that you're going to be able to write applications based on types so that you write an application once for 4th person for example, and then that application is going to be able to run on any page that exposes 4th person information.
But this is a step where you choose your data source.
It can be data from any of these sources mentioned.
And this is basically where you were.
The writer application which is.
Which is PHP and it's a very very easy interface, so you you you have a code to start with and then you just modify that.
And at the end of the day, you get this.
Nation and you can share it with the entire world.
OK, so.
This is very new, but already the reception is very very encouraging.
So basically we're talking to a lot of people who are very large content publishers on the web and they are all very, very enthusiastic, and they're all very, very busy.
And adding, adding microformats or RDF a markup to their pages.
So from what I can see is I can easily say that the size of the annotated value easily has grown by factors.
Since we have started with this project.
By virtue of people wanting to participate in this.
The direction of developers is also very enthusiastic.
We had a developer launch party three weeks ago in California and we had 300 people there, so that's pretty good.
We already have a couple of 1000 applications, so that's pretty good.
Of course, a lot of it is just people copying the sample application and modifying it a bit, but still, it's a nice number.
There are some very obvious next steps.
That is going beyond this kind of surface applications and actually using using the metadata for for ranking for increasing relevance through a better understanding of query intent.
Also there is work inside inside Yahoo and the search part of Yahoo on on focusing on task completion instead of single results and their metadata will probably also come into play.

There's a general trend towards opening up more more of search and and other parts of Yahoo so that you're going to be able to write these kind of applications against our mobile platform against against the front page against other parts of Yahoo.
And also complexity is going to increase so.

So obviously these applications are very simple and that they work on on just metadata related to a single page, but there are going to be more complex applications that work on metadata, for example that comes back for the entire query.
So if you want to know more you can you can go to developerjava.com.
And you can play with search monkey.
There are some mailing lists that you can join.
For both developers and site owners, and you can also make suggestions at the links.

Which one?

It should be open completely.
Interesting.

You know how does this relate to the semantic web?
And you will hopefully find the answers there, but I'm also interested in your questions.

Images.
